importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, marking a recent aviation safety event at Hong Kong International Airport and triggering immediate emergency response and operational suspensions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident happened around 3:50 a.m. local time, during the early morning arrival of a cargo flight from Dubai, which is critical for establishing the timeline of the accident and its immediate aftermath.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines, flying under an Emirates flight number, skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) during arrival from Dubai around 3:50 a.m. local time.
The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon skidding off the runway and collided with an airport security patrol car, which was killed in the impact, resulting in two fatalities.
The aircraft was partially submerged, with the tail section snapped off and significant damage to the front section below the cockpit.
All four crew members were treated at local hospitals and confirmed safe; there was no cargo on board.
No distress signals were sent by the pilots; the flight did not indicate any problems during approach, according to Hong Kong’s Civil Aviation Department.

Hong Kong International Airport suspended operations on its north runway until the aircraft is removed from the sea, though two other runways remain active and operations continue without major disruption.
The aircraft was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides extra cargo capacity to major airlines like Emirates.
Despite being one of the world’s busiest airports, fatal aviation accidents are rare at HKIA, with the last major crash being in 1999.

The former Kai Tak Airport, located in a densely populated area, was historically one of the world’s most difficult airports for landings, highlighting the significance of the current airport's safety record.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines, flying under an Emirates flight number, skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) during arrival from Dubai around 3:50 a.m. local time. The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact and collided with an airport security patrol car, resulting in the deaths of two staff members in the vehicle. The aircraft sustained severe damage, with the tail section broken off and the front section heavily damaged, though all four crew members were treated and survived. No distress signals were sent by the pilots. The airport suspended operations on the north runway until the aircraft is removed, though other runways remain operational, minimizing disruption to over 1,000 daily flights. The flight was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major airlines like Emirates. The incident is notable given HKIA’s strong safety record, with the last major crash occurring in 1999 at the former Kai Tak Airport, historically regarded as one of the world’s most difficult airports for landings.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
